instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
Hey all, have a water damaged board that has no backlight. There wasn't any corrosion or red pads when I got it, and it doesn't look like anyone has tried working on it. I verified that there's a display, just no backlight.

F9700 was blown, so I replaced it, and now get a green light but no power. I'm getting a short to ground somewhere along the line now.

If I remove <RESISTOR>R0910</RESISTOR>, since it's before the <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> line for <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> but doesn't remove <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL>, it powers on just fine. But that means that it'll boot when I kill <SIGNAL>PPBUS_SW_BKL</SIGNAL>. All the caps seem to be fine from there to the LCD connector J9000, but something is obviously shorting. What is the SW0 and SW1 do?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message: I take it back. Tested a new LCD and LCD Cable and SHUBAAAM backlight and image. Guess it's that simple.
